awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Collaborative Research: Harnessing Big Data for Improving Career Mobility
awd_abstract_narration:
U.S. college students are facing critical challenges for their career development and job mobility, which is vital for their long-term career success, especially during global pandemic times. Indeed, the questions that often puzzle students include what career choices to choose next, how to update skills for future new jobs, and which learning opportunities to take. These challenges have been increasingly observed among different groups of students in different majors and socioeconomic statuses at many universities. This project collects and analyzes academic curriculum and student career data, discovers useful patterns about college curriculum and students’ career development, studies students’ career choices, and develops sophisticated solutions to improve their career mobility. This study makes significant contributions to the fields of data mining, machine learning, and education and career data analytics. The results of this project can bring new ways for understanding and improving college graduates’ career success, provide useful insights and tools for students to make their decisions on career development, and augment the service capability of college career and academic advising offices. This project integrates the research with education through new course module development, involving graduate and undergraduate students in research, and research showcases for local K-12 students. 

This project focuses on the following three specific aims (SA): mining and informing useful semantics and patterns about college curriculum and graduates’ career development; studying the career choices of college graduates; and developing sophisticated solutions to improve career mobility of college graduates. To achieve the first SA, this project develops a novel context-aware deep learning method for mining semantics from heterogenous textual data and discovers insightful horizontal and vertical patterns. To solve the second SA, this project mines multiple-scale career path patterns and develops a new hierarchical neural network method to model and predict graduates’ career choices. To achieve the third SA, this project develops novel reinforcement learning methods to recommend learning items for both graduated students and enrolled ones.  The results of this project will be disseminated in the form of peer-reviewed publications, publicly available data set, tutorials, seminars, and workshops.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: MIS Dept. at The University of Arizona

por.por_cntn:
This project has achieved several key outcomes, including groundbreaking research and practical applications to improve education and career mobility.

 

1. Large Data Collection

We gathered extensive information from job postings, course descriptions, and career profiles. This data was messy, but we cleaned and organized it to make it useful for analyzing trends and patterns.

2. Innovative AI Models

Using advanced machine learning, we created tools to better understand jobs, course materials, and career histories. These tools don’t just focus on text but also consider the order of events and connections between data points. This helps us build applications like finding similar career paths or recommending jobs to workers.

3. Uncovering Bias in Career Data

 By studying career patterns, we found differences in how groups, like men and women, progress in their careers. These differences were linked to biases in how data represents employees. We also discovered that these biases lead to unfair outcomes in applications like job matching. To address this, we developed a new method to reduce bias in career data analysis.

4. Better Career Recommendations

We tackled challenges like the "cold-start problem" (where recommendations struggle for new users) and ensuring fairness and diversity in job suggestions. Using creative techniques like learning from smaller datasets and generating additional data, we built and tested solutions that work effectively.

5. Student Training and Success

Several PhD students worked on this project, incorporating the findings into their dissertations. One of them has already graduated and secured a faculty position in Australia.

6. Teaching Integration

The project’s results have been integrated the PI's multiple courses.Several PhD students contributed to this project, using its findings to enrich their research and dissertations. One of these students has successfully graduated and is now a faculty member at a university in Australia, highlighting the project's role in advancing academic and professional careers.

 

In summary, this project has advanced our understanding of career development and education, created novel methods and tools to make job recommendations more accurate and fair and learn more effective feature representations of education and career data, and provided valuable training for students and educators. This project has yielded broader impacts on academic research, education and labor markets. 

 


Last Modified: 01/18/2025
Modified by: Yong Ge
por.por_txt_cntn:
This project has achieved several key outcomes, including groundbreaking research and practical applications to improve education and career mobility.





1. Large Data Collection


We gathered extensive information from job postings, course descriptions, and career profiles. This data was messy, but we cleaned and organized it to make it useful for analyzing trends and patterns.


2. Innovative AI Models


Using advanced machine learning, we created tools to better understand jobs, course materials, and career histories. These tools dont just focus on text but also consider the order of events and connections between data points. This helps us build applications like finding similar career paths or recommending jobs to workers.


3. Uncovering Bias in Career Data


By studying career patterns, we found differences in how groups, like men and women, progress in their careers. These differences were linked to biases in how data represents employees. We also discovered that these biases lead to unfair outcomes in applications like job matching. To address this, we developed a new method to reduce bias in career data analysis.


4. Better Career Recommendations


We tackled challenges like the "cold-start problem" (where recommendations struggle for new users) and ensuring fairness and diversity in job suggestions. Using creative techniques like learning from smaller datasets and generating additional data, we built and tested solutions that work effectively.


5. Student Training and Success


Several PhD students worked on this project, incorporating the findings into their dissertations. One of them has already graduated and secured a faculty position in Australia.


6. Teaching Integration


The projects results have been integrated the PI's multiple courses.Several PhD students contributed to this project, using its findings to enrich their research and dissertations. One of these students has successfully graduated and is now a faculty member at a university in Australia, highlighting the project's role in advancing academic and professional careers.









In summary, this project has advanced our understanding of career development and education, created novel methods and tools to make job recommendations more accurate and fair and learn more effective feature representations of education and career data, and provided valuable training for students and educators. This project has yielded broader impacts on academic research, education and labor markets.
